body_html:
Hi @aroraakshit -- I imagine it's been frustrating to have to go through so many places to find an answer, but hopefully we can figure out what's happening here.

It would help to make a simpler example, to extract the possibility that it's something inside the model that's raising an error. Can you create a minimal example that starts with a tf.example holding an int, and a SavedModel from a model_fn that just accepts that int and doesn't actually do any learning? That will isolate whether this is an issue inside the model, or in the communication between the client and the server.

body:
Hi @aroraakshit -- I imagine it's been frustrating to have to go through so many places to find an answer, but hopefully we can figure out what's happening here. 

It would help to make a simpler example, to extract the possibility that it's something inside the model that's raising an error. Can you create a minimal example that starts with a tf.example holding an int, and a SavedModel from a model_fn that just accepts that int and doesn't actually do any learning? That will isolate whether this is an issue inside the model, or in the communication between the client and the server.
